comments.commentBody:
Donald Trump apparently intends to adorn the 2016 GOP Convention with an array of guys he deems as "winners," such as Ben Rothlisberger and Bobby Knight. Now, if only he can find a serial abuser and/or repeat sexual assaulter with an Hispanic surname, presto, his Latino problem should be solved.

www.endthemadnessnow.org

"Quoting Dick Armey, the former House Republican leader from Texas, the report cautioned, “You can’t call someone ugly and expect them to go to the prom with you.”"

Do Republicans want Hispanics to "go to prom" with them for one night to show them off and then dump them, or are they looking for a long term, mutually beneficial relationship?

Is there a Republican who can say that the latter its the truth with a straight face?

The Republicans have, at least in the short term, put themselves in a catch 22 position. They have built as their base, starting with Reagan, a largely mean minded, racist, misogynist bunch of aging white men. And they're stuck with them.
They have already made their choice. McConnell said they just want control of the White House. Ryan said he can work with 'President' Trump. Le jeux sont faits.

An important part of the GOP's disintegration is its refusal to distinguish and call out facts from lies, rational from irrational POVs and perhaps worst of all, the resulting acceptance of hatred. In the upcoming presidential election, the true dividing line between Americans who embrace or tolerate this Republican party's brand of politics and those who reject it will stand up and be counted.

I hope to see America's true greatness emerge by the resounding rejection of this GOP's feckless and amoral behavior.

Why is the focus on what is better for the Republican or Democratic parties instead of on what is better for America? Our country’s founders hoped that we would form temporary coalitions to support specific legislation. They foresaw a future in which an ordinary citizen might form a group with some people to support one particular issue, and be in a completely different group in support of another issue.

What a shame that we now identify with permanent parties, and let party leaders decide our stance on all issues, especially since this stance is decided on what is good for the party rather than for the nation.

It is time for the GOP to regroup and get real. The neocon voices are diminished, and now the hard right economic and social “theologians” are muted. Whether they like it or not the base has veered to the middle economically. The path that the GOP has been taking up to now, has now reached its’ logical dead end with this current debacle. Loosing an election is not the end of the world. With cognitive behavior and justice for all the USOA will last for many elections. It is time for the GOP to unite forces with the progressives to defeat the GOP’s current trumpery candidate. The USOA must come before the Party. All must work to steer the ship of state down the middle of the creek, too much right or too much left are dead ends on the banks.

Come on, it's about actions.  If they are not willing to meet the special needs of minorities they won't vote for you.  You can't get women to think you want to be fair if you push the Catholic/Evangelical abortion wackiness.  Women can figure it out themselves, let them.  You are not going to get the youth vote if you try to keep them from voting, restrict access to colleges by keep raising cost from tuition to loan rates.  You can't change the tone of the discourse if you scream hate and anger at the opposition at every stop.  You certainly can't talk about impeachment.

"I won't vote for Hillary" is no excuse to vote for Trump. We don't put a racist, a fascist, a con-man, an unstable personality who knows nothing of U.S. policy in the White House because... email.

Many Times readers know very little about Mrs Clinton. True, she may have been in the news for 30 years, but what most people remember is the Republican mudslinging, innuendo and utter nonsense. People can't say why she is "the most qualified" candidate for president.

Similarly, Donald Trump is a fictional TV character with a carefully crafted playboy image. Today's story of his casino business adds heft to his bio.

If the media would present Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Trump without the snarky presumptions and the hype, voters would have a better understanding of the choice.

A consolidated (less bi-partisan) Latino vote has been openly afforded a reason-to-be.

There shan't be confused apathy this November, because DJT has so willfully/ wittingly explicitly challenged an extensive, expansive element.

He is rolling dice.

I can't envision the Florida GOP getting as much Cuban-American vote, as it has been doing for many years.

It is much about explicit ethnic politics, and it's not pretty.

And I am not claiming Trump doesn't gain non-Latino voters in the phenomenal issue.

The White lower middle class and people of color in that same class should be economic allies. Rather the elite and the GOP play on racial fears to drive them a part. The same forces have been active in our country since the beginning. and especially around the civil war.

Now the drying up of jobs which has effected both whites and people of color has stoked a further competition and the fears that this engenders. And the GOP is in the middle of this as usual. I do not have an answer because it seems that often fear Trumps the unity that should be the answer . But it is whites who must wake up to their own interests and see how the GOP and their rich masters rig the game.

"Donald Trump has emerged as the party’s standard-bearer while scapegoating Latinos and other minorities to stoke the fears and resentment of working-class white voters."

this gives donald trump too much credit for insight and forethought. no, i really think that he's saying what he feels...in the moment.

the simplest explanation really is the best....
The GOP is relatively diverse: They have white Americans with dark, blond, grey, white or red hair. Their eye colors vary too!

We will find out right away whether the Latinos will imitate the current crop of cowards in leadership positions with the GOP, Ryan, McConnell, and McCain among them, or have the courage to respond intelligently to the threat of Trumpery.

They could have stopped him in the early days, right after his famous "they are rapists...", but why stop someone who is screeching all the values that the GOP has had for years? I think they were giddy with joy, not realizing that he is not
controllable. Theres the rub! Now live with it, and suffer the consequences
which will reverberate, and haunt them.

Less than 40 percent of eligible Hispanic-Americans showed up to vote in 2012 (even though their 10 percent share of the electorate was the highest ever). African-American turnout was around 65 percent, followed by 63 percent for whites.

Maybe Trump is the one who finally succeeds at what democrats have failed for years: Get Latinos to the polls in large numbers... to vote against him.
The irony.

"“But the focus for a lot of politicians here is the short term. A lot of them don’t think they’ll be in politics in 20 years.”"

Of course not. Why would they when they can go cash in and make a fortune as a lobbyist? Latino, black, white--irrelevant when the real color that matters is the color of money.

The entire Republican economic platform is pro-corporation and anti-people, pro-rich and anti-poor. I don't see them gaining large enough majorities of voters without hiding this fact. And part of the hiding has been scapegoating the poor minorities of all kinds. Without that, how will they confuse the people enough to get their votes?

I infer that the editorial board is inattentive, they should be commending the republicans for valiantly sticking with their core principles: single minded pursuit of a mix of racial segregation, perversion of law and order, redefining of laws to favor the rich, produce a consequence free society for their acolytes. Their strategy after Romney's loss was clear: "We hate them, but they (Hispanics, blacks, women, immigrants) voted for a Black Kenyan Muslim Socialist over Romney. Now, we should get them to vote for us." Premise of this strategy? They mistook "them" as facsimiles of the congregants of their hate-spewing churches, and the church of FOX - who do as told.

So Trump happens. The religious right, the vanguard of hate-mongering and uncompromising supporter of racial injustice in the US, embraces Trump over those who promised a theocracy (Santorum, Huckabee). Imagine that.

Republicans will reform. As in, they will become more angry, spiteful, and mean. They will redouble their efforts to stonewall and burn down the village until the hapless villagers agree to let them be in charge for no other reason than that they want to be in charge. Or was the editorial board plain not paying attention when Newt and his later acolytes shut the government down until we all obeyed, never mind that the majority of Americans had put someone else in power.

Kalidan

Many people argue they are against illegals only, but it's been an all out assault against minorities. Republicans started to pass laws disenfranchizing minorities voters as soon as they could, with some politicians admiting that was their goal. It's been policies against Affirmative Action, against subsidized housing, Planned Parenthood and other programs helping poor people, especially where those people are minorities.
Not all the Hispanics support Immigration Reform, but most are worried about being treated as suspects if there are attempts to deport illegals. And, as others have pointed out, not all Republicans are racist, but if you are a racist there is a good chance you are a Republican.
I also want to point out that many of these positions exist within the Democrats and we need to convince them why they need to support minorities more.

The Republican Party is totally bankrupt. They deny evidence and facts, going with their gut instincts, instead. They won't even pay heed  to data their own people collected after their drubbing in 2012. They show how insane they are: doing the same thing over and over again and expecting different results. Be it Bromback in Kansas or Ryan in Congress, all they do is retread old failed policies. They deserve to fail.

When will the NYTimes acknowledge that the country has been invaded by Latinos that are overwhelming the social support structure (jobs, welfare, medical care, schools, crime, ...)? Trains headed from Guatemala with hundreds of migrants camped on them headed here have to stop, otherwise people like Trump will keep showing up. I was in a discussion last night with two "Democrats" here in California and they are voting for Trump as a "protest" against all this unchecked illegal immigration. Enforce the law, stop illegals and deport illegals that are here and there will be no Trump.

Trump is not the problem. His supporters are. He's just an avatar to the Republican base: a relatively small group of nasty, greedy, sociopathic, self-centered and racist people. The Republican Party decided to cater to them and now they're having a problem controlling the monster they created. Good luck with that.
Mitt Romney got 27 percent of the Latino vote in 2012. Trump will struggle to get 20 percent this time.

It's exactly Op-Eds like these that stoke the fire or racial animosity rather than address the issue which is at hand - many Americans are NOT happy with BOTH parties for their support of ILLEGAL immigration and their lack of addressing the issues of the voters, especially the economy and jobs.

Hispanics are not a uniform voting block and if they think that helping illegals ( which a majority are Hispanic, at this time) is what this country needs, then by all means vote accordingly. But for the rest of us, who believe in the rule of law, and who came to the US by legal means, illegals are a slap in our face, and that includes Hispanics who immigrated legally.

The Republicans now have a candidate that finally reflects the views of many who don't think it's OK to come or stay illegally. And we don't want our resources to be used for people who aren't part of our system.

Each must vote according to their conscience, but it's clear that both legal (H1B, etc.) and illegal immigration is being supported by the establishment and the laws flouted by companies. The losers - the American citizen, taxpayer, and voter, among others (like small business).

Keep fanning the flames of this, NYT, but the voters have had enough. It's about the economy, no matter how much you'd like it to be about racism, xenophobia or however you and the elite, mainstream media, professional activists and establishment politicians, like to falsely frame this story.
